posts.name: Gavin Precurato
posts.cooked:
During this season, our team wasn’t able to buy the correct gearboxes for our arm, so we weren’t able to properly utilize a PID loop or any control system for our arm since there was so much chain slack (Just a “stop when the arm encoder reaches this height”) Now that we have them, I’m really having a hard time understanding how to implement a proper PID loop and was wondering how I would go about it.

Here is our current code repo Our arm swings through the robot, so it goes a little over 90 degrees forward and backwards: 3193 1024×1024 153 KB

3193 1024×1024 153 KB

3193 1024×1024 153 KB

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Good looking bot.

Careful not to fall into the XY problem trap. But from the context you provided it sounds like chain tension was the issue. I would like to address this first:

How does the new gearbox solve the chain tension issue (or other modifications)? Has this been addressed? Do you have ways to remove slack in the future when the chain stretches? There are a lot of good ways to tension chain that have been explored on this website.

… And just because others will bring it up what you are likely looking for is a PID + feed forward. PID will drive the arm towards position, feed forward will help “go past” that to supply a force to counteract gravity. Useful since you are going out both sides of the bot. (See mechanical counterbalancing later in this post)

New gearbox may mean the mechanism drops rather quickly when the bot loses power (like when the breaker is turned off intentionally). You may want to look into mechanical counterbalancing to take up some of this force to make things less “guillotine-esque”. You may want to bring this up with mechanical. This is often done in FRC with gas springs on the arm itself, bypassing backlash (although it may introduce a little complexity in the PID because things aren’t necessarily linear, but they were not to begin with, so I would not worry about this too much)

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: Have you looked at the WPILib Tuning a Vertical Arm Position Controller doc ?

link_counts.title: Tuning a Vertical Arm Position Controller — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Gavin Precurato
posts.cooked: forgot to mention, we are using two gas shocks that can hold up most of the weight of the arm, but it gets a little iffy towards the top once the arm extends so far out to reach the high node especially. That is where most of our problem lies.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Excellent! Now I see them looking at the picture, they blend in. This “almost weightless” sounds about right in terms of balance; take a lot of the load off of the motor. I am sure it’s a little weird to balance with the extension of the arm (changing center of mass) - to be expected.
